Agenda â— â— â— â— â€œClassicâ€ search and its limitations ML model and usage Vector search or hybrid search in Elasticsearch OpenAIâ€™s ChatGPT or LLMs with Elasticsearch
Elasticsearch You Know, for Search
These are not the droids you are looking for.

Elasticsearch You Know, for Vector Search
What is a Vector ?
Embeddings represent your data Example: 1-dimensional vector Character Vector [ î‚ˆ1 î‚„ Realistic Cartoon î‚ƒ1î‚„
Multiple dimensions represent different data aspects Human Character Vector [ î‚ˆ1, 1 î‚„ Realistic Cartoon Machine î‚ƒ 1, 0 î‚„
Similar data is grouped together Human Character Vector [ î‚ˆ1.0, 1.0 î‚„ î‚ƒ 1.0, 0.0 î‚„ Realistic Cartoon [ î‚ˆ1.0, 0.8 î‚„ î‚ƒ 1.0, 1.0 î‚„ [ î‚ˆ1.0, î‚ˆ1.0 î‚„ Machine
Vector search ranks objects by similarity (~relevance) to the query Human Rank Query 1 Realistic Cartoon 2 3 4 5 Machine Result

Choice of Embedding Model Start with Off-the Shelf Models Extend to Higher Relevance â—Text data: Hugging Face (like Microsoftâ€™s E5î‚‚ â—Apply hybrid scoring â—Images: OpenAIâ€™s CLIP â—Bring Your Own Model: requires expertise + labeled data
Problem training vs actual use-case
Architecture of Vector Search
How do you index vectors ?

Eland Imports PyTorch Models Co m m er ci al $ eland_import_hub_model â€”url https://cluster_URL â€”hubmodel-id BERT-MiniLM-L6 â€”tasktype text_embedding â€”start BERT-MiniLM-L6 Select the appropriate model Load it Manage models

Elasticâ€™s range of supported NLP models Co m m er ci â— Fill mask model Mask some of the words in a sentence and predict words that replace masks â— Named entity recognition model NLP method that extracts information from text â— Text embedding model Represent individual words as numerical vectors in a predefined vector space â— Text classification model Assign a set of predefined categories to open-ended text â— Question answering model Model that can answer questions given some or no context â— Zero-shot text classification model Model trained on a set of labeled examples, that is able to classify previously unseen examples Full list at: ela.st/nlp-supported-models al
How do you search vectors ?

Vector Query GET product-catalog/_search { â€œqueryâ€ : { â€œboolâ€: { â€œmustâ€: [{ â€œknnâ€: { â€œfieldâ€: â€œdesc_embbedingâ€, â€œnum_candidatesâ€: 50, â€œquery_vectorâ€: [0.123, 0.244,â€¦] } }], â€œfilterâ€: { â€œtermâ€: { â€œdepartmentâ€: â€œwomenâ€ } } } } }, â€œsizeâ€: 10

Vector Query Transformer model Co m m er ci al GET product-catalog/_search { â€œqueryâ€ : { â€œboolâ€: { â€œmustâ€: [{ â€œknnâ€: { â€œfieldâ€: â€œdesc_embbedingâ€, â€œnum_candidatesâ€: 50, â€œquery_vector_builderâ€: { â€œtext_embeddingâ€: { â€œmodel_textâ€: â€œsummer clothesâ€, â€œmodel_idâ€: <text-embedding-model> } } } }], â€œfilterâ€: { â€œtermâ€: { â€œdepartmentâ€: â€œwomenâ€ } } } }, â€œsizeâ€: 10 }

But how does it really work?
Similarity: cosine (cosine) Human q cos(Î¸) = d1 d2 Realistic Î¸ qâƒ— Ã— d âƒ— | qâƒ— | Ã— | d |âƒ— _score = 1 + cos(Î¸) 2

Similarity: Euclidean distance (l2_norm) y 2 n i (x âˆ‘ 1 i= âˆ’ y i) q l2_normq,d = y1 d x1 y2 x2 n âˆ‘ i=1 (xi âˆ’ yi) 1 _score = 1 + (l2_normq,d )2 x 2
Brute Force

Hierarchical Navigable Small Worlds (HNSWî‚‚ One popular approach HNSW: a layered approach that simplifies access to the nearest neighbor Tiered: from coarse to fine approximation over a few steps Balance: Bartering a little accuracy for a lot of scalability Speed: Excellent query latency on large scale indices

Filtering KNN Vector Similarity Automatically choose between brute force and HNSW Brute force (not real numbers; used only to demonstrate the linearity) HNSW Bound worst case to 2*(brute force) â€¢ Brute force scales O(n) of filtered â€¢ HNSW scales ~O(log(n)) of all docs
Elasticsearch + Lucene = fast progress â¤

Scaling Vector Search Vector search Best practices

  1. Needs lots of memory
  2. Avoid searches during indexing
  3. Indexing is slower
  4. Exclude vectors from _source
  5. Merging is slow
  6. Reduce vector dimensionality 4. Use byte rather than float
  • Continuous improvements in Lucene + Elasticsearch

Reduce Required Memory 2. Reduce of number of dimensions per vector

  1. Vector element size reduction (â€œquantizeâ€)
Benchmarketing
https://github.com/erikbern/ann-benchmarks
Elasticsearch You Know, for Hybrid Search
Hybrid scoring Term-based score Linear Combination manual boosting Vector similarity score Combine

GET product-catalog/_search { â€œqueryâ€ : { â€œboolâ€ : { â€œmustâ€ : [{ â€œmatchâ€: { â€œdescriptionâ€: { â€œqueryâ€: â€œsummer clothesâ€, â€œboostâ€: 0.1 } } },{ â€œknnâ€: { â€œfieldâ€: â€œdesc_embbedingâ€, â€œquery_vectorâ€: [0.123, 0.244,â€¦], â€œnum_candidatesâ€: 50, â€œboostâ€: 2.0, â€œfilterâ€: { â€œtermâ€: { â€œdepartmentâ€: â€œwomenâ€ } } } }], â€œfilterâ€ : { â€œrangeâ€ : { â€œpriceâ€: { â€œlteâ€: 30 } } } } } } summer clothes pre-filter post-filter

Hybrid ranking Term-based score Dense vector score Reciprocal Rank Fusion (RRFî‚‚ blend multiple ranking methods Combine Sparse vector score

Reciprocal Rank Fusion (RRFî‚‚ D î‚ˆ set of docs R î‚ˆ set of rankings as permutation on 1..|D| k - typically set to 60 by default Ranking Algorithm 1 Doc Ranking Algorithm 2 Score r(d) k+r(d) A 1 1 B 0.7 C D E Doc Score r(d) k+r(d) 61 C 1,341 1 61 2 62 A 739 2 62 0.5 3 63 F 732 3 63 0.2 4 64 G 192 4 64 0.01 5 65 H 183 5 65 Doc RRF Score A 1/61 î‚ 1/62 î‚› 0,0325 C 1/63 î‚ 1/61 î‚› 0,0323 B 1/62 î‚› 0,0161 F 1/63 î‚› 0,0159 D 1/64 î‚› 0,0156
